notes: used for both genders; very common polite “you”

shortphrases.thai: แล้วคุณล่ะ
shortphrases.english: And you? — Uses คุณ as polite “you”
you all — Polite plural “you”

longphrases.thai: คุณสบายดีไหม

longphrases.thai: ทำไมคุณกินแล้ว

longphrases.thai: คุณวิ่งไหม
longphrases.english: did you run? — Yes/no; tense from context

longphrases.thai: คุณกินเท่าไหร่
longphrases.english: how much did you eat? — Polite “you”

sentences.thai: พวกคุณยังกินอยู่ไหม
sentences.romanization: phûak khun yang gin yùu mái
sentences.english: are all of you still eating? — Polite “you” inside plural “พวกคุณ”

sentences.romanization: khun yang dern yùu dâai yang-ngai
sentences.english: how are you still walking?! — Polite “you”

notes: appears in “สบายดี”; base adjective

shortphrases.english: I’m fine — Basic response to “How are you?”
not well / sick — Often used when talking about being sick

longphrases.thai: คุณสบายดีไหม
longphrases.english: Are you well? / How are you? — สบาย = comfortable / well; in greetings means “fine / well”

longphrases.thai: ผมสบายดีครับ
longphrases.english: I’m fine (male, polite) — Part of the “I’m fine” pattern

longphrases.thai: ฉันสบายดีค่ะ

longphrases.thai: ผมไม่สบายครับ
longphrases.english: I’m not well (male, polite) — Literally “not comfortable”

longphrases.thai: ฉันไม่สบายค่ะ
longphrases.english: I’m not well (female, polite) — Often used when you’re ill

notes: modifies many phrases; in greetings means “fine”

shortphrases.english: I’m fine — Often understood as “(I’m) fine / (I’m) good”

longphrases.thai: คุณสบายดีไหม
longphrases.english: Are you well? / How are you? — ดี = good; part of the pattern “สบายดี”

longphrases.english: I’m fine (male, polite) — Literally “I comfortable good”

longphrases.thai: ฉันสบายดีค่ะ
longphrases.english: I’m fine (female, polite) — Same structure as male version

notes: placed at end of a question

longphrases.thai: คุณสบายดีไหม
longphrases.english: Are you well? / How are you? — ไหม is the yes–no question particle

longphrases.thai: คุณยังอ่านอยู่ไหม
longphrases.english: are you still reading? — Yes/no question

longphrases.thai: ได้ไหมครับ
longphrases.english: can (I/you)? / is it okay? — Yes–no question particle

longphrases.thai: ได้ไหมคะ
longphrases.english: can (I/you)? / is it okay? — Yes–no question particle

longphrases.thai: คุณวิ่งไหม
longphrases.english: did you run? — Question particle

longphrases.thai: ผมกินได้ไหม
longphrases.english: can I eat? — Question particle

sentences.thai: พวกคุณยังกินอยู่ไหม
sentences.romanization: phûak khun yang gin yùu mái
sentences.english: are all of you still eating? — Question marker

sentences.romanization: phûak kháo jà bpai wîng mái
sentences.english: are they going to go running? — Question marker

notes: negates verbs/adjectives; tone always falling

shortphrases.english: not well / sick — Literally “not comfortable”; used to say you’re ill
No (male, polite) — Common polite “no” for male speakers
No (female, polite) — Common polite “no” for female speakers

longphrases.thai: ผมไม่สบายครับ
longphrases.english: I’m not well (male, polite) — ไม่ = no / not

longphrases.thai: ฉันไม่สบายค่ะ
longphrases.english: I’m not well (female, polite) — Negative particle

notes: final particle for most polite female speech

shortphrases.english: No (female, polite) — Can stand alone as a full reply

longphrases.thai: ฉันสบายดีค่ะ
longphrases.english: I’m fine (female, polite) — Polite ending particle for female speakers (statement tone)

longphrases.thai: ฉันไม่สบายค่ะ
longphrases.english: I’m not well (female, polite) — Polite female ending

notes: final particle for most polite male speech

shortphrases.english: No (male, polite) — Can stand alone as a full reply

longphrases.thai: ผมสบายดีครับ
longphrases.english: I’m fine (male, polite) — Polite ending particle for male speakers

longphrases.thai: ผมไม่สบายครับ
longphrases.english: I’m not well (male, polite) — Polite male ending

longphrases.thai: ได้ไหมครับ
longphrases.english: can (I/you)? / is it okay? — Male polite particle

notes: male speakers only

shortphrases.english: And what about me? (male) — Male “I”
I (male) will go — Polite male “I”; used by men/boys in most situations

longphrases.thai: ผมสบายดีครับ
longphrases.english: I’m fine (male, polite) — ผม = I (male speaker)

longphrases.thai: ผมไม่สบายครับ
longphrases.english: I’m not well (male, polite) — Useful when you’re sick

longphrases.thai: ผมกินได้ไหม
longphrases.english: can I eat? — Male “I”; women often use ฉัน

notes: general “I” but more common for women

shortphrases.thai: แล้วฉันล่ะ
shortphrases.english: And what about me? (female) — Female / common “I”
I (female) will go — Common polite “I” for women; also used in formal speech

longphrases.thai: ฉันสบายดีค่ะ
longphrases.english: I’m fine (female, polite) — ฉัน = I (common, esp. female)

longphrases.thai: ฉันไม่สบายค่ะ
longphrases.english: I’m not well (female, polite) — Same meaning with female pronoun

notes: used in “แล้วคุณล่ะ” | After the verb to show completion (ทำแล้ว = already did it)

shortphrases.thai: แล้วคุณล่ะ
shortphrases.english: And you? — Follow-up question after answering about yourself
And what about me? (male) — Uses แล้ว + ล่ะ “then what about…?”

shortphrases.thai: แล้วฉันล่ะ
shortphrases.english: And what about me? (female) — Same structure with female “I”
I already ate — Very common particle for “already / finished”
I already ran — แล้ว shows the action is done/completed
I already sat — Shows the action is finished/completed

longphrases.thai: ทำไมคุณกินแล้ว
longphrases.english: why did you eat already? — Marks completion / “already”

notes: follows nouns/pronouns; “แล้ว…ล่ะ?”

shortphrases.thai: แล้วคุณล่ะ
shortphrases.english: And you? — ล่ะ marks “what about…?”
And what about me? (male) — “what about…?”

shortphrases.thai: แล้วฉันล่ะ
shortphrases.english: And what about me? (female) — “what about…?”

notes: used in polite leave-taking; base of “ลาแล้ว”
Very common everyday verb; can also mean “to eat/drink” in casual speech

shortphrases.english: I am eating — Basic verb “to eat”; here with กำลัง as present continuous
I already ate — แล้ว after the verb marks completion / “already”

longphrases.thai: ยังกินอยู่
longphrases.english: I am still eating — Same verb “eat”; อยู่ at the end keeps it ongoing

longphrases.thai: จะไปกิน
longphrases.english: I will go eat — Verb “eat”; action planned for the future

longphrases.thai: ทำไมคุณกินแล้ว
longphrases.english: why did you eat already? — Verb “eat”

longphrases.thai: ผมกินได้ไหม
longphrases.english: can I eat? — Verb “eat”

longphrases.thai: คุณกินเท่าไหร่
longphrases.english: how much did you eat? — Verb “eat”

sentences.thai: พวกคุณยังกินอยู่ไหม
sentences.romanization: phûak khun yang gin yùu mái
sentences.english: are all of you still eating? — Eat

notes: Used for going/heading somewhere; often combined with time/place words

shortphrases.english: will go — Very common “will go”; can be followed by place or time
go (to) run — Pattern “ไป + verb” = go do something
go (to) walk — Can mean go for a walk / stroll
I (male) will go — Often followed by destination or time
I (female) will go — Can be expanded: ฉันจะไปไทย “I will go to Thailand”

longphrases.thai: จะไปกิน
longphrases.english: I will go eat — ไป = go; here “go (and) eat”

longphrases.thai: จะไปวิ่ง
longphrases.english: I will go run — “Go (and) run”; can add place or time after

longphrases.thai: เราจะไปวิ่ง
longphrases.english: we will go running — Go (and)

longphrases.thai: เราจะไปไหน
longphrases.english: where are we going? — Go

longphrases.thai: คุณจะไปเมื่อไหร่
longphrases.english: when will you go? — Go

sentences.thai: พวกเขาจะไปวิ่งไหม
sentences.romanization: phûak kháo jà bpai wîng mái
sentences.english: are they going to go running? — Go (and)

notes: Future marker placed before a verb (จะไป, จะกิน); also used to express intention

shortphrases.english: will go — จะ is the future marker “will”; goes before the verb
I (male) will go — Future marker; comes between pronoun and verb
I (female) will go — Same future marker จะ, works the same for any subject

longphrases.thai: จะไปกิน
longphrases.english: I will go eat — จะ before a verb = “will / going to” (future or intention)

longphrases.thai: จะไปวิ่ง
longphrases.english: I will go run — Same future marker จะ = “will”

longphrases.thai: เราจะไปวิ่ง
longphrases.english: we will go running — Future / intention

longphrases.thai: เราจะไปไหน
longphrases.english: where are we going? — Future / intention marker

longphrases.thai: คุณจะไปเมื่อไหร่
longphrases.english: when will you go? — “will / going to”

longphrases.thai: ใครจะเล่น
longphrases.english: who will play? — Future marker “will”

sentences.thai: พวกเขาจะไปวิ่งไหม

sentences.english: are they going to go running? — Future marker

longphrases.thai: พวกเขายังเดินอยู่
longphrases.english: they are still walking — Walk

sentences.thai: คุณยังเดินอยู่ได้ยังไง
sentences.romanization: khun yang dern yùu dâai yang-ngai
sentences.english: how are you still walking?! — Verb “walk”

notes: Used for playing games, sports, instruments, or casually using things (เล่นมือถือ = be on your phone)

longphrases.thai: ใครจะเล่น
longphrases.english: who will play? — Verb “play”

notes: To sit; also used for “ride as a passenger” (นั่งรถ = ride in a car)

shortphrases.english: I already sat — Verb “sit”; can also mean “sat down already”

shortphrases.thai: นั่งตุ๊กตุ๊ก
shortphrases.english: ride a tuk-tuk — Phrase used for riding in a tuk-tuk

notes: To stand; contrasts with นั่ง (sit)
To run/jog

shortphrases.english: go (to) run — Often used for exercise/jogging
I already ran — Base verb “run”; past/completed because of แล้ว

longphrases.thai: จะไปวิ่ง
longphrases.english: I will go run — Verb “run / jog”; often used for exercise

longphrases.thai: เราจะไปวิ่ง

longphrases.thai: คุณวิ่งไหม
longphrases.english: did you run? — Verb “run / jog”

sentences.thai: พวกเขาจะไปวิ่งไหม
sentences.romanization: phûak kháo jà bpai wîng mái
sentences.english: are they going to go running? — Run/jog

notes: To read (books, messages, etc.)

longphrases.thai: คุณยังอ่านอยู่ไหม
longphrases.english: are you still reading? — Read

notes: To write/draw; used for writing text or sometimes drawing simple things
Basic verb “to do/make”; combines with the markers below (กำลังทำ, ทำอยู่, ทำแล้ว, จะทำ)

longphrases.thai: คุณทำอะไรอยู่

notes: Marks ongoing action; usually before the verb (กำลังทำ = am doing)

shortphrases.english: I am eating — กำลัง before a verb marks an action happening right now (present continuous)

definition: continuous marker at the end of a sentence
notes: At end of the clause to show ongoing action (ทำอยู่ = am doing it right now)

longphrases.thai: ยังกินอยู่
longphrases.english: I am still eating — อยู่ at the end marks a continuing action

longphrases.thai: พวกเขายังเดินอยู่
longphrases.english: they are still walking — Continuous marker

longphrases.thai: คุณยังอ่านอยู่ไหม
longphrases.english: are you still reading? — Ongoing action

longphrases.thai: คุณทำอะไรอยู่

longphrases.thai: โทรศัพท์อยู่ไหน
longphrases.english: where is the phone? — Location verb “to be (at/in)”

sentences.english: are all of you still eating? — Continuous

sentences.english: how are you still walking?! — Continuous marker

notes: With ไม่ for “not yet” (ยังไม่ทำ = haven’t done yet); alone can mean “still”

longphrases.thai: ยังกินอยู่
longphrases.english: I am still eating — ยัง before the verb = “still”; shows action not finished

longphrases.thai: พวกเขายังเดินอยู่
longphrases.english: they are still walking — Indicates “still”

longphrases.thai: คุณยังอ่านอยู่ไหม
longphrases.english: are you still reading? — Still

sentences.thai: พวกคุณยังกินอยู่ไหม
sentences.romanization: phûak khun yang gin yùu mái
sentences.english: are all of you still eating? — Still / not done

sentences.thai: คุณยังเดินอยู่ได้ยังไง
sentences.romanization: khun yang dern yùu dâai yang-ngai
sentences.english: how are you still walking?! — “still / yet”

notes: Before verb for past experience/habit (เคยทำ = have done before / used to do)
Before verb for “just did” (เพิ่งทำ = just did it recently)
Often with จะ for near future (เดี๋ยวจะทำ = I’ll do it in a moment)
Used by both genders; also means “I” in informal contexts depending on region

shortphrases.english: we all — “We / us”

longphrases.thai: เราจะไปวิ่ง
longphrases.english: we will go running — จะ = future marker; ไปวิ่ง = go run

longphrases.thai: เราจะไปไหน
longphrases.english: where are we going? — เรา = we; can be “I” casually

notes: Same word for “he” and “she”; context determines meaning

shortphrases.english: they — “They (group of them)”

longphrases.thai: พวกเขายังเดินอยู่
longphrases.english: they are still walking — ยัง = still; อยู่ = continuous

sentences.thai: พวกเขาจะไปวิ่งไหม
sentences.romanization: phûak kháo jà bpai wîng mái
sentences.english: are they going to go running? — Future + question pattern

notes: Adds plural meaning (พวกเขา = they; พวกเรา = we all; พวกคุณ = you all)

shortphrases.english: you all — พวก makes the pronoun plural
we all — Explicit plural form
they — Plural marker added

longphrases.thai: พวกเขายังเดินอยู่
longphrases.english: they are still walking — ยัง = still; อยู่ = continuous

sentences.thai: พวกคุณยังกินอยู่ไหม
sentences.romanization: phûak khun yang gin yùu mái
sentences.english: are all of you still eating? — Future/continuing group “you all”

sentences.thai: พวกเขาจะไปวิ่งไหม
sentences.romanization: phûak kháo jà bpai wîng mái
sentences.english: are they going to go running? — Future + question pattern

notes: Used for animals and objects; casual/rude for people
General “what”; can stand alone as a question (อะไร?) or follow a noun

longphrases.thai: คุณทำอะไรอยู่
longphrases.english: what are you doing? — “what”

notes: “At what place”; common for “where?” questions
“When?” (past or future); often written เมื่อไร in text

longphrases.thai: คุณจะไปเมื่อไหร่
longphrases.english: when will you go? — “when”

notes: Same word for “who” as subject or object

longphrases.thai: ใครจะเล่น
longphrases.english: who will play? — “who?”

notes: Used after the noun or alone for “which one?”

longphrases.thai: ไหนก็ได้
longphrases.english: whichever / any is fine — Choice is open; “any is okay”

longphrases.thai: เราจะไปไหน
longphrases.english: where are we going? — “where / which place”

longphrases.thai: โทรศัพท์อยู่ไหน
longphrases.english: where is the phone? — Question word “where / which (place)”

notes: General “why?”; works in most situations

longphrases.thai: ทำไมคุณกินแล้ว
longphrases.english: why did you eat already? — “why?”

notes: Very common casual spoken “how?”

sentences.thai: คุณยังเดินอยู่ได้ยังไง
sentences.romanization: khun yang dern yùu dâai yang-ngai
sentences.english: how are you still walking?! — Casual “how?”

notes: Used with verbs and in questions like …ได้ไหม to ask “can / is it okay?”

longphrases.thai: ไหนก็ได้
longphrases.english: whichever / any is fine — ได้ here = acceptable / okay

longphrases.thai: ได้ไหมครับ
longphrases.english: can (I/you)? / is it okay? — Male polite question

longphrases.thai: ได้ไหมคะ
longphrases.english: can (I/you)? / is it okay? — Female polite question

longphrases.thai: ผมกินได้ไหม
longphrases.english: can I eat? — “can / allowed to”

sentences.thai: คุณยังเดินอยู่ได้ยังไง
sentences.romanization: khun yang dern yùu dâai yang-ngai
sentences.english: how are you still walking?! — “can / able to”

notes: “Or” between choices; also appears at the end of a sentence as a softer question
Often used alone with money or amounts (เท่าไหร่? = how much?)

longphrases.thai: คุณกินเท่าไหร่
longphrases.english: how much did you eat? — “how much / how many”

notes: Must be followed by a classifier (e.g., กี่คน, กี่เล่ม)
Used at the end of most questions by women or when calling someone (rising tone)

longphrases.thai: ได้ไหมคะ
longphrases.english: can (I/you)? / is it okay? — Female polite particle (question)

notes: Flexible linker; in ไหนก็ได้ it helps give the meaning “whichever / any is fine”

longphrases.thai: ไหนก็ได้
longphrases.english: whichever / any is fine — Connects ไหน and ได้; makes the phrase natural

notes: General classifier for objects; can stand in when you don’t know the specific classifier
“This” near the speaker; often follows the noun (บ้านนี้ = this house)
“That” further away or already mentioned
Common for both “house” and “home”
Can mean car or vehicle more generally
Usually “telephone”; often just “phone”

longphrases.thai: โทรศัพท์อยู่ไหน
longphrases.english: where is the phone? — Literally “phone be-at where?”

notes: Any kind of book
Table or desk, depending on context
Key for locks (house, car, etc.)
Generic bag, purse, or backpack

shortphrases.thai: กระเป๋าสตางค์
shortphrases.english: wallet — Literally “bag”; part of the compound “money bag”

notes: General word for shoes
Subunit of Thai baht; 100 สตางค์ = 1 บาท; mostly seen on price tags

shortphrases.thai: กระเป๋าสตางค์
shortphrases.english: wallet — “Money / small change”; with กระเป๋า = “wallet”

notes: Naturally pairs with โต๊ะ (table)
Door or gate depending on context
Common everyday word for “America / the U.S.”

shortphrases.thai: ประเทศอเมริกา
shortphrases.english: America (USA) — Country name “America / the U.S.”

notes: Short common form of กรุงเทพฯ; can also use full กรุงเทพมหานคร
Used for countries in general; often before the country name

shortphrases.english: Thailand — Literally “country Thailand”

shortphrases.thai: ประเทศอเมริกา
shortphrases.english: America (USA) — “Country America”

notes: City/town; also used in many place names
Core idea = “run out / be finished / all gone.” In ทั้งหมด (tháng mòt) it means “all of it / the whole amount.”

shortphrases.english: all; in total — “Finished / all gone”; together = “all / in total”

notes: Base meaning “kind/type” or “manner/way.” In ทุกอย่าง (thúk yàang) it’s “every kind (of thing)” → “everything.”

shortphrases.english: everything — “Kind / type / way”; here “every kind (of thing)”

notes: Used for “the whole … / all (of)” (ทั้งวัน = the whole day, ทั้งบ้าน = the whole house)

shortphrases.english: all; in total — “Whole / entire”; part of ทั้งหมด

notes: Basic “every/each” before classifiers or nouns (ทุกวัน = every day, ทุกคน = everyone)

shortphrases.english: everything — “Every”; together with อย่าง = “everything”

notes: Demonym “Thai”; also used as adjective (Thai food, Thai language, etc.) depending on context

shortphrases.english: Thailand — Component word meaning “Thai”
